title: DA tracker always reports error
body:
#59110

I get

```
debugAdapterError: Error: read error
debugAdapterExit: 130
``` 

every time when debugging ends. Do you see that? I'm not sure about the exist code but the "read error" error seems like it comes from vscode every time the DA stdout closes, isn't that expected?

title: Auto save in new settings results in multiple validation errors when typing text
body:
Continuing discussion from #58537

> Steps to Reproduce:
> 
> Open new settings editor, search for "emmet extension"
> Emmet: Extensions Path is a setting that takes path to a directory. Start typing a path
> Since we auto-save in 100ms, the config change event is fired for almost every other character typed, which results in validation checks from the emmet extension resulting in a series of error notifications.
> 
> There might be other extensions in the marketplace that do such validations after listening the config change event.

title: Extend tasks API to allow programmatic problem matching

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
The new tasks APIs (fetchTask(), executeTask(), task events...) makes it more convenient to use vscode's own task system to spawn child process (as opposed to using something like `child_process`, for example). Still, AFAICT, there are two bits missing in the API:

1. A method to get the underlying `Terminal` instance of a running task (maybe through `TaskExecution`?);

2. Events that would be fired whenever something is written in the process' stdout/stderr (that would probably go in the `Terminal` instance itself)

This would be very useful to implement UI feedback (i.e progess notifications) while using vscode's task system. Right now, the only way I see to do that is to spawn my own proces, create an output channel and handle problem matching myself...

Does that make sense?

title: ModuleEvent raised by Debug Adapter has no effect

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.27.2
- OS Version: Windows 10, x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Debug Adapter extension, or modify vscode-mock-debug sample
2. Set supportsModulesRequest = true in initializeRequest
3. Implement modulesRequest
4. Implement a way of raising a ModuleEvent with reason="new", for example in the REPL loop's call to evaluateRequest
5. Set a breakpoint in your modulesRequest
6. Test the extension. Trigger the ModuleEvent. The breakpoint in modulesRequest isn't hit. Nor is there any visible change to the VSCode UI

I guess it's possible that VSCode doesn't yet make use of the Module capabilities of the DA protocol.

title: Show full line in search results
body:
After updating to 1.27.2 (I don't know the exact prior version I was on), search results only show a very small part of the line that the result is in. I can only assume that this change was intentional, so I'm filing this as a feature request: 

Please add an option to show the full line of each search result — I need more context to judge which search result is the one I'm looking for. It can be very confusing to not even see the beginning of the line. (There are people asking about this on StackOverflow already: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52488545/show-full-line-in-search-results)

Alternatively, it would be great to optionally show even more context (i.e. lines above and below the search result) similar to what Sublime Text does.

title: Terminal resolves symlink path
body:
- Open a folder under a symlinked path. After #18837 vscode doesn't resolve the symlinked path anymore
- Open a terminal
- The terminal opens with a cwd which is the resolved symlink path

This is mentioned in #18837 and https://github.com/Microsoft/node-pty/pull/156 already addressed this but was closed.

title: Formatted comments/documentation

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Documentation is painful to read when reading plain (C#/[insert language]) code. You must perform human parsing on the xml elements.

It would be great if there can be different rendering based on the type of AST node you're in, starting and ending with a line.

---

Instead of this:
https://imgur.com/a/x1deCKZ
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/46601639-00d84200-caee-11e8-9048-b9cc2b84af74.png)

---

I want this:
https://imgur.com/a/AuhIL7q
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/46601649-07ff5000-caee-11e8-96d8-a5ac7849656c.png)

---

To achieve this, I imagine some sort of renderer registered to certain AST nodes (CommentRenderer for CommentNode). 

*Edit*: Inlined images

title: Column selection issue with ctrl+shift+arrows
body:
I left a question about this column selection issue on stackoverflow.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52241239/column-selection-issue-with-ctrlshiftarrows

But I didn't get reply and I'm thinking this feature is not supported by vscode.
So, I'm trying to raise a new feature request.

When I use column selection, cursors are not arranged like this.
![olwvg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30585126/45923101-b369ab80-bf17-11e8-85ef-7ec8b4822bce.png)

This disarrangement of cursors breaks structure of code when rearranging code.

Atom editor does keep the arrange of cursor like this
![gbsak](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30585126/45923109-ca100280-bf17-11e8-8f49-c9590da5c2f3.png)

So, it supplies good functionality for rearranging code structure

I wonder if there is preference option for this and if not I hope that will be provided in the future as new feature.

Thanks.

title: VSCode is trying to enable bluetooth without a reason. It's a privacy issue
body:
VSCode is trying to enable bluetooth. I don't know why. I can't realize why a code editor will need bluetooth for any reason, and indeed is a privacy issue.

I cant see that on my system log every time I open VSCode:

If I open VSCode and next:
```
$ journalctl -xe | grep code
sep 22 18:43:29 hostname dbus-daemon[407]: [system] Activating via systemd: service name='org.bluez' unit='dbus-org.bluez.service' requested by ':1.2018' (uid=1000 pid=24366 comm="/opt/visual-studio-code/code ")
```
Same problem with extensions disabled
```
$ journalctl -xe | grep code
sep 22 18:49:25 hostname dbus-daemon[407]: [system] Activating via systemd: service name='org.bluez' unit='dbus-org.bluez.service' requested by ':1.2038' (uid=1000 pid=24918 comm="/opt/visual-studio-code/code --disable-extensions ")
```

- VSCode Version: 1.27.2
- OS Version: GNU/Linux with kernel 4.14.71-1-lts (it occurs in other kernels too)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode
2. Check system log with journalctl

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: launch command limited to 1024 characters

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.28.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.13.6

Steps to Reproduce:

*This is how I discovered the issue, but it's not specific to `runtimeVersion`.  I'm not sure if variable expansion is something that can happen, but if it could, outputting `env "PATH=/path/to/node/version:${PATH}"` would seemingly be a workaround.*

*Apologies if this is a dupe; I searched but nothing was jumping out at me.*

1. Set `PATH` to something approaching 1024 characters.  One way to do this, evidently, is to use zsh & antigen with a bunch of plugins.  :smile: [Example of large `PATH` here](https://gist.github.com/boneskull/b7f99a0c51a3254d28a882b17d6289c4); you could also just add a bunch of nonsense via something like
    ```json
    "env": {
      "FOO": "<insert 1024 random characters here>"
    }
    ```
1. Launch VS Code
1. Add a launch config containing `runtimeVersion`, such as:
    ```json
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "node-red",
      "runtimeExecutable": "node",
      "runtimeVersion": "8.1.2",
      "program": "app.js",
      "console": "integratedTerminal",
      "internalConsoleOptions": "neverOpen"
    }
    ```
1. Start debugging.  Terminal will show something like this: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/924465/45902355-0ec25f00-bd9b-11e8-95fb-5a95042911de.png)
 That's a limit of 1024 characters. You can ignore the `%`

1. Once timeout is hit, you should see this alert: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/924465/45902279-dd499380-bd9a-11e8-9e46-1a99c26f5508.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Git: Expose blame information in API

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'd like to request new method be added to the Git extension API detailed in:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/git/src/api/git.d.ts

My use case for this are is that in my extension [MarkDown To-Do](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=TomasHubelbauer.vscode-markdown-todo) I currently shell out to Git to get blame for a line in order to determine the age of a MarkDown checkbox (`- [ ] checkbox`) on that line.

This feature request is prompted by @joaomoreno after his comment in #48674.

title: Undo should always be in view before making changes
body:
**Issue**
1. Open a large file (one that requires scrolling in the editor).
2. Make a single edit.
3. Scroll out of view of the edit.
4. Undo the edit using keyboard shortcut.

**Current Functionality**
Edit is undone and then that line is put into view with the cursor position set.

**Desired Functionality**
Line is first put into view with the cursor position set. The undo operation must then be performed again before the edit is undone. (For reference, this is the default functionality in WebStorm).

title: Symbolic links should respect explorer decorations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.27.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 18.04

Steps to Reproduce:

Create a workspace in `/mnt/a/b/c/worspace.code-workspace`. Add a git repository to it with active changes. Open the workspace using the File menu and all decorations will be displayed correctly. Close the workspace before exiting vscode. Now create a symbolic link `/home/x/` to `/mnt/a` and open the workspace using the File menu and `/home/x/b/c/worspace.code-workspace`. The Source Control menu will still show all changes, but the explorer will no longer display the decorations. This error does not occur when opening the workspace via the console.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Recent projects in Welcome should be sorted by last closed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
### Use case

1. First thing in the morning, I open the Angular project I'm working on
2. Through the day, I open some of my other projects, to check/copy previous code
3. At the end of the day, the main project I'm working on is the last one closed

Tomorrow morning I'd love to have it show up first in the list (not behind the more button)

Searched in the settings, couldn't find an option to toggle this

title: editor.action.selectHighlights automatically

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I really like being able to see all the occurrences of something I highlight easily. Atom has this capability and I don't see any reference to this being a default feature in Code.

I would like to highlight a string and highlight occurrences of that string, automatically, in the same file, but also all other files that are open. This commonly comes up when I'm verifying prop-drilling in react applications. Props are often named the same across different components and it would be great to see the logical flow at a glance and all the references to these across files.

title: Allow for block relation line colors.
body: I am trying to see if you can update the colors for each block relation line. Similar to how [Bracket Pair Colorizer](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=CoenraadS.bracket-pair-colorizer) extention works when coding JS in VSCode. Nothing is more annoying than tracking the same color line down. As you can see in the pic they are all light gray. It would be nice to have a couple different colors... like grandparent = light green, parent light blue, child light red - repeat down or the option to put 3 colors of your choice in. Stackoverflow - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52415082/how-can-you-change-the-block-relation-line-colors-in-vs-code?noredirect=1#comment91776609_52415082

title: Please add MIME type for .code-workspace file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
A Visual Studio Code workspace file is currently recognised in Linux as a normal plain text file. This is because there isn't a MIME type for this file. Applications can provide additional MIME types as described here: 

https://developer.gnome.org/integration-guide/stable/mime.html.en

Not having a MIME type has a couple of issues, for example the files are shown as plain text files in the GUI, which makes it hard to distinguish source code files from the workspace file. This slows down navigating to a workspace and opening it.

*Find the workspace in the following screenshot*

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1492981/45818239-6a301680-bce1-11e8-8770-984d9127bda8.png)

It's currently impossible to theme such a file because it's not seen as a different MIME type: https://github.com/snwh/suru-icon-theme/issues/87#issuecomment-417743275

title: Feature request: advance cursor to the next line of code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: I currently have a macro set up to run the current line or select, and move the cursor down one line. However, sometimes the next line is blank, only has an indentation, or is commented. I'd like the ability to advance instantly to the next line which has code that can actually be run.

title: moving TypeScript files in explorer fails to update/prompt imports when containing folder is moved
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.27.2
- OS Version: Win 10
- Typescript: 3.0.3

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Set update imports on move typescript setting to prompt
1. Create an empty project with 2 typescript files, one importing from the other.
2. In the explorer manually move the depended upon file to a new directory. You will be prompted to update the import. This works fine. 
3. Now move that directory into ANOTHER new directory.
4. This time there is no prompt and the import will be broken
